name: Integrate Microsoft Defender for Office 365 with the Phish Alert Button (PAB)
title: Integrate Microsoft Defender for Office 365 with the Phish Alert Button (PAB)
body:
You can integrate the Phish Alert Button (PAB) with Microsoft Defender for Office to send emails to Microsoft’s Submissions page for analysis. In the Microsoft 365 Defender platform, the Submissions page receives emails that users report with Microsoft’s Report button. With this integration, you can allow your users to report suspicious emails to your organization and your Submissions page with the PAB. When users report KnowBe4’s simulated phishing emails with the Report button, Microsoft can mistakenly classify these emails as threats. This integration also helps Microsoft recognize KnowBe4’s simulated phishing emails and avoid false positives for users’ reported emails.

Prerequisites

Before you configure this integration, you'll need to enable and configure the PAB in your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see the Enable and Configure section of our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual.

You'll also need to enable the Microsoft 365 Defender for Office service for your organization’s mail server. Then, configure a security operations (SecOps) mailbox for your Microsoft account so that emails can be sent to your Submissions page. For more information, see Microsoft's Use the Microsoft 365 Defender portal to configure SecOps mailboxes in the advanced delivery policy article.

Important:Microsoft Defender requires that emails be in EML format.

Configuring the Integration

To configure this integration, you’ll need to allow third-party reporting tools for your Microsoft 365 Defender platform. For more information, see Microsoft’s Options for third-party reporting tools article. To allow the third-party reporting tools, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft 365 account using your admin credentials.
  2. Navigate to the Microsoft 365 Defender portal > Settings > Email & collaboration.
  3.  Click User reported settings. Or, you can access the User reported settings page by navigating to https://security.microsoft.com/securitysettings/userSubmission.
  4. On the User reported settings page, select the Monitor reported messages in Outlook check box to enable the reporting options.
  5. Under the Select an Outlook report button configuration section, select Use a non-Microsoft add-in button.
    Important:If you select this option, Microsoft's Report button will be disabled automatically.
  6. Under the Send reported messages to: drop-down menu, select My reporting mailbox only or Microsoft and My reporting mailbox.

    Note:If you select Microsoft and my reporting mailbox, any reported messages will be automatically sent to Microsoft for analysis. For more information, see Microsoft's Options for third-party reporting tools section of their User reported settings article.
  7. In the Add an exchange online mailbox to send reported messages to: field, enter the email address associated with your Microsoft account’s Submissions page and SecOps mailbox.
    Note:Enter the same email address you used to configure your SecOps mailbox. For more information, see Microsoft's Use the Microsoft 365 Defender portal to configure SecOps mailboxes in the advanced delivery policy article.
  8. (Optional) You can select the Allow reporting for quarantined messages. Only admins can report quarantined Teams messages. check box to allow your users to report emails from their quarantine folder.

After you have configured these settings in Microsoft 365 Defender, you’ll need to configure the integration in your KSAT console. To configure the integration in KSAT, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Click your email address in the top-right corner of the page. From the drop-down menu that opens, select Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to Account Integrations > Phish Alert.
  4. Click the plus icon next to the PAB instance to view your settings.
  5. Select the Enable Microsoft 365 Defender Integration check box.
  6. In the Submit Reported Emails to: field, enter the email address associated with your Microsoft account’s Submissions page and SecOps mailbox.
    Important:In addition to entering the email address associated with your Microsoft account, you can enter a different email address in the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: field to provide a copy of users’ reported emails to your organization’s admins. If you only want to send reported emails directly to your SecOps mailbox, leave the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: field empty.
  7. (Optional) You can select the Save a copy of reported emails check box if you would like the PAB to save a copy of reported emails in the Sent folder of the user who reported them.
  8. Click the Save Phish Alert Settings button.
  9. At the bottom of the page, click the Save Changes button.

User Experience

Once you've configured the integration, your users can use the PAB to report suspicious emails to both KnowBe4 and Microsoft.

When a user reports an email, they must select a disposition. By default, they can select the Phishing/Suspicious or Spam/Junk disposition. If you have enabled the User Comments and Email Disposition feature, your users can also add comments and select the Unknown disposition.

If a user selects the Unknown disposition, the reported email is initially labeled as Phishing in Microsoft’s Submissions page. For more information, see our Phish Alert Button (PAB) User Comments and Email Disposition Guide.

Note:Microsoft’s Submissions page cannot receive emails that contain multiple attachments or files with comments. If a user adds a comment when they report an email, the comment file will not be included in the copy of the reported email sent to the Submissions page.

After a user reports an email, the email will be deleted from their inbox, and two copies of the reported emails will be sent. The first copy will be sent to the email address entered in the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: field in your KSAT Account Settings. The second copy will be sent to the email address in the Submit Reported Emails to: field in your KSAT Account Settings, associated with Microsoft Defender’s Submissions page. If the Save a copy of reported emails setting is enabled, a copy of the reported email is also saved in the user’s Sent folder.

Once an email is submitted to Microsoft, it will display in the User reported tab on the Submissions page of your Microsoft 365 Defender portal within a few minutes.

images.alt:
This image displays the **Settings** configuration page within a security or compliance management application, likely part of the Microsoft Defender or Microsoft 365 ecosystem.

**UI Structure and Navigation (Left Panel):**

The left navigation pane lists main feature categories. The bottom section is visible, showing:
*   **Health**
*   **Permissions**
*   **Settings** (Highlighted with callout **1**, indicated by a gear icon and currently selected).

The section above shows:
*   **Cloud apps** (Expanded, showing **Cloud discovery**, **Cloud app catalog**, **OAuth apps**, etc.)
*   **Policies** (Collapsed)
*   **Reports**
*   **Audit**

**Main Content Area (Settings Page):**

The primary content area is titled **Settings**. It features a two-column list view with headers: **Name** and **Description**.

The visible items in the settings list are:

| Name (Icon) | Description |
| :--- | :--- |
| **Security center** (Gear) | General settings for the Microsoft 365 security center |
| **Microsoft 365 Defender** (Shield) | General settings for Microsoft 365 Defender |
| **Endpoints** (Monitor/Laptop) | General settings for endpoints |
| **Email & collaboration** (Email/Tag, highlighted) | General settings for email & collaboration (Highlighted with callout **2**) |
| **Identities** (Person icon) | General settings for identities |
| **Device discovery** (Network/Device) | Select your device discovery mode and customize standard discovery settings |
| **Cloud Apps** (Cloud) | General settings for cloud apps |

This image is a partial screenshot of a technical configuration interface, likely a web application, displaying navigation and content for managing user reporting features.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Breadcrumb Navigation:** The current location is indicated by the path: `Settings > Email & collaboration`.
*   **Vertical Navigation Pane (Left):**
    *   The link **"User reported settings"** is highlighted, enclosed in an orange/red rectangular outline, and is the currently active selection, indicated by a light gray background fill.
    *   Subsequent links are listed below, including **"User tags"** and **"Priority account protection"**.
*   **Main Content Pane (Right):**
    *   **Page Title:** The header is a large, bold, black text reading **"User reported settings"**.
    *   **Descriptive Text:** Below the title is explanatory text: "Customize how users report messages in Outlook and Teams. Reported [message fragment] on the **Submissions** page. **Learn more about user reported settings.**"
    *   **Hyperlinks:** The words "Submissions" and "Learn more about user reported settings" are active hyperlinks (blue, underlined text is implied by context, though only blue is visible for "Submissions").

This image captures the configuration panel for "User reported settings" within a Microsoft security or administration portal, focused specifically on controlling how users report messages in Outlook.

**Page Title and Context:**
*   **Header:** User reported settings.
*   **Description:** "Customize how users report messages in Outlook and Teams. Reported messages will be sent to the mailbox of your choice and appear on the [Submissions] page. [Learn more about user reported settings]." (The terms "Submissions" and "Learn more about user reported settings" are active links).

**Outlook Settings Section:**
*   **Sub-Header:** Outlook
*   **Monitoring Control:** A checked checkbox labeled "Monitor reported messages in Outlook" is active, indicating that message reporting is enabled.

**Outlook Report Button Configuration:**
The section "Select an Outlook report button configuration" presents two mutually exclusive options, accompanied by schematic diagrams and an information icon (i) next to each primary label.

1.  **Built-in Report Button (Unselected):**
    *   **Radio Button State:** Unselected.
    *   **Label:** "Use the built-in Report button in Outlook."
    *   **Visual Aid:** A diagram illustrating a mail client interface where a dropdown button labeled "Report" provides sub-options: "Phishing," "Junk," and "Not junk."
    *   **Nested Configuration (Active when selected):** The sub-header "When the Report button is clicked:" is followed by two checked checkboxes, suggesting default behavior if this option were active:
        *   "Show a pop-up message before email is reported" with a link "Customize before message."
        *   "Show a pop-up success message after email is reported" with a link "Customize after message."

2.  **Non-Microsoft Add-in Button (Selected):**
    *   **Radio Button State:** Selected (blue dot).
    *   **Label:** "Use a non-Microsoft add-in button."
    *   **Visual Aid:** A diagram illustrating a mail client interface that prominently features a generic add-in button icon (a grid of squares) placed within the message view pane, indicating the use of a third-party reporting tool.

This technical screenshot displays the **User reported settings** configuration page, accessible via the breadcrumb path `Settings > Email & collaboration`.

**Navigation Context (Left Panel):**
The active tab is `User reported settings`. Other tabs include `User tags`, `Priority account protection`, and `Microsoft Teams protection`.

**Main Configuration Elements:**
1.  **Reporting Method:** A radio button is selected for `Use a non-Microsoft add-in button`.
2.  **Microsoft Teams Integration:** The setting `Monitor reported messages in Microsoft Teams` is visible (checkbox appears unselected).
3.  **Reported message destinations (Highlighted Focus):**
    *   The section header is `Reported message destinations`.
    *   A large orange arrow directs attention to the `Send reported messages to:` dropdown menu.
    *   The dropdown is expanded, showing the following destination options for user-reported messages:
        *   `Microsoft only`
        *   `My reporting mailbox only`
        *   `Microsoft and my reporting mailbox` (This option is currently selected/highlighted).

This image depicts a segment of a configuration screen, likely within a Microsoft 365 or Exchange Online administrative interface, focusing on settings for user-reported messages and email notifications.

**Section 1: Reported message destinations (Highlighted in orange)**
*   **Title:** Reported message destinations (Bold text).
*   **Description/Input:** "Add an exchange online mailbox to send reported messages to:" followed by an input field. The content of the input field is blurred/redacted, but appears to contain a single email address placeholder or partially entered address.

**Section 2: Email notifications**
*   **Title:** Email notifications (Bold text).
*   **Context:** "Notifications are available only if you use the built in **Report** button in Outlook or Microsoft Teams."

**Subsection: Results email**
*   **Header:** Results email.
*   **Action Link:** "Customize results email" (Blue hyperlink).

**Subsection: Customize sender and branding**
*   **Header:** Customize sender and branding.
*   **Option 1 (Checkbox):** Unchecked. Text: "Specify a Microsoft 365 mailbox to use as the From address of email notifications" followed by an information icon (ⓘ).
*   **Option 2 (Checkbox):** Unchecked. Text: "Replace the Microsoft logo with my organization's logo across all reporting experiences." followed by a hyperlink: "Learn more about customizing your organizational branding."

**Section 3: Reporting from quarantine**
*   **Title:** Reporting from quarantine (Bold text).
*   **Option (Checkbox):** Checked (blue checkmark). Text: "Allow reporting for quarantined messages. Only admins can report quarantined Teams messages."

This image displays a configuration screen titled "Phish Alert." The interface is organized into expandable sections detailing settings for an email phishing alert and reporting system.

**General Settings:**

*   A primary toggle is enabled: **"Enable Phish Alert"** (checked).
*   A hyperlink allows viewing of user activity: **"See PAB User Activity."**
*   A collapsible configuration panel, currently expanded, is labeled **"— KB4 Tech Content 1 Settings."**

**Core Configuration Fields:**

*   **Setting Name:** Text input field (content redacted).
*   **Icon:** Includes a browse button and an illustration of an envelope being caught by a fishing hook.
*   **License Key:** Text input field (content redacted).
*   A checkbox option **"Limit CRID Validation"** is unchecked.
*   **Send Non-Simulated Emails to:** A large text input field for multiple email addresses (content redacted), followed by the instruction "Separate multiple email addresses with a comma."
*   An action button is present: **"Add PhishER Email Address."**
*   A checkbox option **"Send Us a Copy"** is unchecked.

**Office Add-in Settings:**

This section contains a group of checkboxes and input controls, all preceded by a question mark icon (indicating available tooltip/help information).

*   **Email Format:** Dropdown menu set to **"EML."**

*   **Left Column (Highlighted by an orange bounding box):**
    *   Checkbox **"Enable Microsoft 365 Defender Integration"** (checked).
    *   Associated input field: **"Submit Reported Emails to"** (content redacted).
    *   Checkbox **"Save a copy of reported emails"** (checked).

*   **Right Column:**
    *   Checkbox **"Autofill Phishing Languages with PAB Locale"** (unchecked).
    *   Checkbox **"Enable Email Forwarding"** (unchecked).
    *   Checkbox **"Exclude original body text from reported emails"** (unchecked).
    *   Checkbox **"Send email headers as TXT attachments"** (unchecked).
images.context: of the user who reported them.

images.alt:
This image displays a modal window titled **"Phish Alert,"** featuring an envelope and fishing hook icon, and a close button ('X').

**Content Sections:**

1.  **Header and Context:**
    *   The primary entity/sender is identified as **KnowBe4**.
    *   A blue tag indicating the platform is present: **M365**.
    *   Instructional text asks: "Are you sure you want to report this as a phishing email?"
    *   The **Subject:** field reads: "You've received a document from eversign."
    *   A blue hyperlink, **"Show Sender's Details,"** is visible for expanding information.

2.  **Email Classification (Radio Buttons):**
    The section labeled **"Email Classification:"** provides three unselected radio button options:
    *   **Phish:** "This email is a threat."
    *   **Spam:** "This email is spam."
    *   **Unknown:** "I'm unsure of this email's disposition."

3.  **Comment Field and Action Button:**
    *   A multi-line text input field is provided with the placeholder text **"Add a comment..."**
    *   A character counter below the field shows **0 / 360**.
    *   The final action button at the bottom is a white, bordered button labeled **"Phish Alert."**
images.context: users can also add comments and select the Unknown disposition.

images.alt:
This image captures a view of a security administration dashboard titled **Submissions**. The view focuses on items submitted or reported by end-users.

**Context and Navigation:**

*   **Page Title:** Submissions.
*   **Selected View:** User reported (one of six available tabs, including Emails, Teams messages, Email attachments, URLs, and Files).
*   **Active Filter:** Date reported (UTC-05:00): Last 7 days.

**Summary Metrics (User Reported):**

The dashboard displays four key count metrics, likely based on Microsoft’s analysis of the user-reported items:
*   Threats: 1
*   Spam: 0
*   No threats: 1
*   Simulations: 10

**Action Bar Elements:**

A toolbar beneath the metrics provides administrative actions:
*   `+ Submit to Microsoft for analysis` (Primary button with a dropdown chevron).
*   `Mark as and notify` (Action button with a dropdown chevron).
*   `Export` (Download icon).
*   `Refresh` (Circular arrow icon).

**Data Grid Headers:**

The list view headers, indicating the columns available for filtering and sorting, include:
*   Name and type
*   Reported by
*   Date reported (UTC-05:00)
*   Sender
